sources.data_found: Turing specifications: 1 'ultra-performance' node (DGX A100); 8 'performance' nodes with 2x NVIDIA Tesla V100 (32GB) each; 4 'teaching' nodes with 4x NVIDIA RTX 2080Ti each.

student_data.notes: Data retrieved from WPI Institutional Research Fact Book (Fall 2023 enrollment). Undergraduate CS count (1,365) refers to BS Computer Science majors. Grad CS count (254) is the sum of MS Computer Science (186) and PhD Computer Science (68). Does not include Data Science or Robotics Engineering majors. [WARNING: Original source was inaccessible, using fallback.]

other_high_vram_gpus.notes: Teaching partition: 4 nodes x 4 GPUs each.

gpu_resources.notes:
Resource counts derived from Turing cluster specifications. 
1) DGX A100 Node: 1 node x 8 A100 (80GB) = 8 GPUs.
2) Performance/GPU Nodes: 8 nodes x 2 V100 (32GB) = 16 GPUs.
3) Teaching Nodes: 4 nodes x 4 RTX 2080 Ti = 16 GPUs.
(Note: WPI also has access to the regional MGHPCC facility, but these listed resources are the specific WPI-owned/managed Turing cluster hardware).

analysis_notes: WPI's primary owned resource is the Turing cluster. The university highlights the acquisition of the DGX A100 (8x A100 80GB) in press releases. The V100 count is derived from the standard configuration of the Turing GPU partition (8 nodes w/ dual V100s) documented in WPI Hub articles and corroborated by student project reports referencing the hardware.
